results.title: Reality bites
results.creator_credit: Ben Stiller, Danny DeVito, Michael Shamberg and Jersey Films
results.brief_description: Reality Bites is Ben Stiller’s directorial debut, and one of the more mainstream offerings in the array of films that emphasized the “Generation X” phenomenon. Lelaina is a recent college graduate out on her own and independent from her supportive, but out-of-touch parents, facing the realities of careers and relationships in the adult world. She can’t stand her internship under a local television personality, and is forced to choose between Michael, a well-intentioned music-video network executive, and Troy, a brooding, sensitive slacker. Meanwhile, she must also protect the artistic integrity of her video documentary that depicts the everyday lives of her friends and herself. Cast includes: Winona Ryder, Ethan Hawke, Ben Stiller, Janeane Garofalo and Steve Zahn.

results.title: The Life of Oharu = Saikaku ichidai onna
results.creator_credit: Kenji Mizoguchi, Hideo Koi, Koi and Shintoho Eiga
results.brief_description: ‘The Life of Oharu’ is an adaptation of Saikaku’s classic novel which traces the tragic riches to rags life of a Japanese woman in 17th century Japan. Told in the form of flashback, the film begins with an elderly Oharu praying before Buddha, reflecting on her life, and her first love. Years ago the well respected Oharu fell in love with a samurai (played by a young Toshiro Mifune), only to lose favour with her family who are exiled for her actions, as well as her love who is promptly beheaded. Her father forces her to become mistress of a great lord in order to bear him an heir, which she does, but is abandoned by the prince after she gives birth. Outcast by the prince, Oharu slides to the lowest rank in society and is forced into becoming a prostitute and beggar. Her life is populated by love and servitude to the men she encounters, as well as the knowledge that her royal son is the one chance she has at escaping her life of poverty and humiliation. The sufferings of the beautiful Oharu (Kinuyo Tanaka) are observed without sentimentality or moralising by Mizoguchi who is acknowledged as being a lifelong advocate of equitable treatment for Japanese women. In Japanese with English subtitles. Cast also includes Ichiro Sugai, Toshiro Yanane and Ataro Shindo.

results.title: Through the olive trees
results.creator_credit: Abbas Kiarostami, Abbas Kiarostami Productions (film company) and Farabi Cinema Foundation
results.brief_description: Iranian cinema in the last two decades of the twentieth century has proved to be one of few national cinemas offering an alternative to the dominance of Hollywood, both in terms of production and in terms of aesthetics. Kiarostami is one of the leading directors of post-revolutionary Iranian cinema and his work is intimately concerned with both the nature of human relationships and the power of cinema to influence and transform life. A film crew arrives in a small town devastated by a recent earthquake. Hossein, a young and homeless bricklayer is given a small role as a newly wed husband. The woman who is to play his wife is Tahereh, the girl he adores but who refuses to have anything to do with him. As the director attempts to get the two young people to play their roles in the script, Tahereh and Hossein enact their own drama and conflict in front of the camera. From this simple material, Kiarostami explores the tensions between men and women, reality and imagination, film and politics, and allows us as an audience to explore the ability of film as an art to seduce us even when it is lying to us. Without the use of special effects, big budgets or imaginary beings, “Through the Olive Trees” transports us to a magical world of human drama that Hollywood could not possibly emulate, no matter how much money or technology lies at its disposal.

results.title: Kwaidan = Woman of the snow
results.creator_credit: Masaki Kobayashi, Shigeru Wakatsuki and Ninjin Club
results.brief_description: Director Masaki Kobayashi’s quartet of self contained ghost stories uses to spellbinding effect highly stylised sets, expressionistic lighting and painterly backdrops in the retelling of 19th century English Orientalist Lafcadio Hearn’s writings. ‘Kwaidan’s‘ (which translates to ghost story) eerie mood is sealed by its mesmerizing and modest credit sequence followed by the first story, the foreboding ‘Shadowings’. The next instalment, ‘Yuki Onna’ (Snow Woman) uses lurid lighting and its contrived studio sets to maximum dream-like effect, while ‘The story of Miminashi Hoichi’ incorporates various modes of ancient Japanese story telling with breathtaking results. Finally, ‘In a cup of Tea’s‘ grimly surreal coda of a publisher’s frustration with the inconclusiveness of many Japanese ghost stories, aptly completes this remarkable anthology. Kobayashi’s meticulous direction, (Kobayashi’s obsessive aesthetic control drove him to hand paint all the sets himself) along with the unsettling soundtrack by Toru Takemitsu make this a unique film experience. In Japanese with English subtitles. Cast includes Keiko Kishi, Tatsuya Nakadai, Kazuo Nakamura, Tetsuro Tamba and Rentaro Mikuni (Awards: Special Jury prize 1965 Cannes Film Festival)

results.title: Highlander [Widescreen]
results.creator_credit: Russell Mulcahy, Peter S. Davis, William N Panzer and Highlander Productions
results.brief_description: From the dawn of time there has been the immortals, destined to live forever and compete for the ultimate prize, duelling against one another until there is only one left with power beyond imagination. Only decapitation can end their immortality. Set in contemporary Manhatten, this fantasy saga follows Highlander Connor Macleod (Christopher Lambert) in a battle against his eternal enemy and main contender for the prize, The Kurgan (Clancy Brown). After being arrested by the police for a fracas in an underground carpark which results in a headless body, Connor must also contend with the inundation of questions, and challenge the notion that immortals cannot fall in love. Connor discovers he is one of the immortals when he is “killed” during a battle in the Scottish highlands by The Kurgan, but miraculously does not die. He learns of his status by fellow immortal Ramirez (Sean Connery), who must cede his immortality by decapitation to make way for a superior contender to battle for the prize. This cult classic makes effective use of flashbacks between past and present and spawned many less superior sequels. Cast includes also Roxanne Hart, Beatie Edney and Alan North. Soundtrack by Queen.

results.title: The Fate of Lee Khan [Widescreen]
results.creator_credit: King Hu, Golden Harvest and King Hu Film Productions
results.brief_description: A martial arts historical epic of deceit, vengeance, treachery and bloody retribution. In 1366 Yuan dynasty China is ruled by Mongol invaders. Lee Khan, a ruthless, decadent aristocrat and master swordsman, and his beautiful but heartless sister, attempt defend their corrupt legacy of privilege and power. They face defeat when group of Chinese national revolutionaries organize and wage a great uprising against their Mongolian oppressors. Cast includes Angela Mao, Hsu Feng, Roy Chiao. In Cantonese with English subtitles.

results.title: Maidens in uniform = Girls in uniform = Madchen in uniform
results.creator_credit: Leontine Sagan, Carl Froelich and Deutsche Filmgemeinschaft
results.brief_description: Central to the film, set in a boarding school for the daughters of German officers prior to World War I, is the intense relationship between a young student and her female teacher. Interwoven emotional and institutional pressures result in near tragedy. The atmosphere of Prussian authoritarianism in the school is expertly evoked and the film has long been seen as an attack on German militarism and was suppressed by the Nazis. Causing an uproar on its release because of its frank handling of lesbianism, it was rediscovered in the seventies and has now taken its place as a classic of gay cinema. Director Leontine Sagan had been trained by Max Reinhardt and was already a prominent stage actress. Soon afterwards she came to England to direct a film for Alexander Korda. Cast includes Dorothea Wieck, Hertha Thiele, Emilia Unda and Ellen Schwannecke. In German with English subtitles.

results.title: Angel of vengeance = Ms.45
results.creator_credit: Abel Ferrara, Navaron Films and Rochelle Films
results.brief_description: Abel Ferrara’s (‘Bad Lieutenant’, ‘King of New York’, ‘Driller Killer’) foray into the revenge fantasy genre is an often unnerving film which owes a lot to Roman Polanski’s disturbing tale of sexual terror, ‘Repulsion’. Set in the rough garment district of New York, ‘Angel of Vengeance’ follows the gradual descent into madness of Thana (Zoe Tamerlis), a mute seamstress who snaps after she is raped twice in one day. Her reaction to it plays like a strange form of liberation, as the once timid seamstress proceeds to off some of the more sleazier male citizens of New York city. Ferrara sprinkles this unusual and stylish low budget film with dark comic moments, eccentric characters (like Thana’s weird landlady played by Editta Sherman), and its slow motion climax is a beautiful and surreal piece of filmmaking. Cast includes Albert Sinkys, Darlene Stuto, Helen McGara, Nike Zachmanoglou.

results.title: Honey, I shrunk the kids
results.creator_credit: Joe Johnston, Penney Finkelman Cox and Buena Vista Pictures
results.brief_description: A non-stop comedy adventure starring Rick Moranis as a preoccupied inventor who has created an electro-magnetic shrinking machine that is accidentally activated and shrinks his children to a minuscule size. After they are caught in the garbage and thrown outside, a visually innovative action packed adventure ensues as the children journey through their backyard and encounter attacking insects, a runaway lawnmower, and swooping bees along the way. A fun and heartwarming family film it is also preceded by a Roger Rabbit short adventure involving Baby Herman and a little medical mayhem in “Tummy Trouble”. Cast also includes Matt Frewer, Marcia Strassman, Kristine Sutherland, Thomas Brown, Jared Rushton.

results.title: Head On
results.creator_credit: Ana Kokkinos, Jill Bilcock, Jane Scott and Head On Productions
results.brief_description: Ana Kokkinos’s debut follows the angry, confused and nihilistic 19-year-old Greek Australian, Ari (Alex Dimitriades) through 24 hours fuelled by drugs, booze and anonymous sex as he grapples with his sexuality and clashes with his traditional Greek family.

constellations_other.name: Ana Kokkinos
constellations_other.description: The films and TV works of Ana Kokkinos often explore the experiences of second-generation Australians, queer identities and class. Since beginning her career in the early 90s, those stories have started to appear more frequently on Australian screens.

results.creator_credit_for_label: Ana Kokkinos, Jill Bilcock, Jane Scott and Head On Productions
results.description:
Based on the novel Loaded by Christos Tsiolkas, Ana Kokkinos’s compelling debut feature Head On is a volatile, confronting and at times bleak look at race, sexuality and class in contemporary Australian society. The film’s lead protagonist Ari (Alex Dimitriades) is an angry, confused, nihilistic, unemployed 19-year-old Greek Australian. The film traces a particularly explosive 24 hours in his life, fuelled by drugs, booze and anonymous sex as he grapples with his sexuality and clashes with his traditional Greek family, who he views with equal amounts of respect and contempt. Performances are excellent throughout, in particular Paul Capsis as Ari’s defiant crossdressing friend Johnny/Toula.

Cast includes Elena Mandalis, Eugenia Fragos, Julian Garner, Dora Kaskanis, Alex Papps, Damien Fotiou. Awards: Best Actor (Alex Dimitriades) and Best Supporting Actor (Paul Capsis) for the 1999 Film Critics Circle of Australia Awards.

Best Feature Film Adaptation (Andrew Bovell, Ana Kokkinos, Mira Robertson) 1998 Awgie Awards.

Best Director (Ana Kokkinos) 1999 San Francisco Lesbian and Gay Film Festival.

Best Achievement in Editing (Jill Bilcock) 1998 AFI Awards.
